channel.title: The Day in Mets History
channel.itunes:author: WonderAI
channel.description:
Step into the world of Mets baseball history with this meticulously crafted daily podcast that unearths compelling stories from the team's rich past. Each 5-7 minute episode transports listeners to a specific date in Mets history, combining masterful storytelling with lesser-known details that even die-hard fans might have missed. From dramatic game-winning moments to behind-the-scenes decisions that shaped the franchise, every episode delivers a slice of Mets heritage with the warmth and authenticity of a conversation at your favorite baseball bar.
The show's deliberate pacing and vintage newspaper-style narration creates an intimate atmosphere that celebrates both milestone moments and overlooked gems. Whether it's reliving a classic game, exploring an impactful trade, or uncovering a quirky footnote in team history, each episode weaves together carefully researched facts with compelling narrative to paint a complete picture of what makes each date special in Mets lore.
Disclaimer: This description is experimental and was generated by AI. It may contain factual errors.
channel.itunes:summary: Daily podcast explores significant dates in Mets history through intimate storytelling and lesser known facts.

itunes:category.text: Sports > Baseball, Sports > History, Arts > Storytelling

item.title: June 26th: When Lightning Struck Twice
item.itunes:title: June 26th: When Lightning Struck Twice
item.description:
A dramatic 14-inning marathon at the Polo Grounds transforms into "The Tim Harkness Game" as the young utility infielder launches a walk-off grand slam to defeat the Chicago Cubs on June 26, 1963. The struggling Mets, in just their second season, create an unforgettable moment when Harkness steps to the plate against Jim Brewer with the bases loaded and two outs, delivering the franchise's first walk-off grand slam. Twenty years later to the day, Rusty Staub etches his own name in baseball history by recording his eighth consecutive pinch hit, tying a major league record. The veteran's remarkable achievement showcases his mastery of one of baseball's most challenging roles, as he would go on to set a record with eleven pinch-hit walks and 81 pinch-hit at-bats that season.
Learn More: • 'The Day in Mets History' (https://wondery.com/shows/the-day-in-mets-history) • 'Ultimate Mets Database: Tim Harkness Game Details' (https://www.ultimatemets.com/gamedetail.php?gameno=235&tabno=B) • 'Rusty Staub: Le Grand Orange - Documentary' (https://primevideo.com/rusty-staub-documentary) • 'The History of the New York Mets - Book' (https://amazon.com/books/history-new-york-mets)
Note: This content was generated using artificial intelligence and may contain factual errors or inaccuracies. Please verify any important information from reliable sources.
item.itunes:summary: Tim Harkness hits walk-off grand slam, Rusty Staub ties pinch-hit record in Mets historic game

item.itunes:keywords: Baseball History, Mets Milestones, Historic Games, Player Achievements

item.title: June 25th: When Mets Magic Strikes Twice
item.itunes:title: June 25th: When Mets Magic Strikes Twice
item.description:
Baseball's poetic symmetry takes center stage as Juan Soto's spectacular two-homer performance at Citi Field mirrors a historic June 25th from Mets lore. In 1976, Mike Phillips transformed an 0-for-21 slump into an unforgettable achievement, hitting for the cycle at Wrigley Field with methodical precision: a single, double, triple, and the crowning home run in the ninth. Fast forward to 2025, and Soto's 27th career multi-homer game writes a new chapter in the ongoing narrative of June 25th magic. The date holds another remarkable footnote from 1989, when the Mets accomplished a defensive rarity in their 5-1 victory over Philadelphia – completing nine innings without a single fielding assist, with every out recorded via strikeout or fly ball. These parallel moments, spanning nearly five decades, showcase baseball's unique ability to weave together past and present, creating connections across generations of players and fans. From Phillips' slump-breaking cycle to Soto's power display, June 25th continues to deliver memorable performances that resonate through Mets history.
Learn More: • 'History Daily: Baseball's Greatest Moments' (https://wondery.com/shows/history-daily/episode/11873-the-black-sox-scandal/) • 'Sports Wars: Baseball After 9/11' (https://wondery.com/shows/sports-wars/season/17/) • 'The Complete History of the New York Mets - Book' (https://amazon.com/books/complete-history-new-york-mets) • 'Baseball's Greatest Games: Historic Cycles' (https://primevideo.com/baseball-greatest-games)
Note: This content was generated using artificial intelligence and may contain factual errors or inaccuracies. Please verify any important information from reliable sources.

item.itunes:keywords: Baseball History, Mets Milestones, Historic Performances, Statistical Anomalies

item.title: June 22: When Seaver Said Goodbye and Washington Shined
item.itunes:title: June 22: When Seaver Said Goodbye and Washington Shined
item.description:
June 22 stands as a pivotal date in New York Mets history, marking both the emergence of a championship contender and the farewell of a franchise icon. In 1969, Jerry Koosman led the surging Mets to a decisive 5-1 victory over the defending National League champion Cardinals at a sun-drenched Shea Stadium, foreshadowing the miraculous season ahead. Exactly eighteen years later, in 1987, Tom "The Franchise" Seaver announced his retirement, concluding a legendary 20-year career that included 311 wins, three Cy Young awards, and an enduring legacy as the heart of the Mets organization. The date also witnessed an unexpected display of power in 1977, when Claudell Washington launched three home runs at Dodger Stadium in a 9-6 victory that snapped a seven-game losing streak. This confluence of events - from the dawn of the Miracle Mets to Seaver's emotional farewell and Washington's remarkable performance - exemplifies baseball's ability to weave together moments of triumph, transition, and individual brilliance into the rich tapestry of a franchise's history.
Learn More: • "Sports Wars: Baseball After 9/11" (https://wondery.com/shows/sports-wars/season/17/) • "American Scandal: Houston Astros" (https://wondery.com/shows/american-scandal/season/56/) • "Tom Seaver: A Terrific Life - Book" (https://www.amazon.com/Tom-Seaver-Terrific-Bill-Madden/dp/1501115219) • "The Miracle Mets: The Story of the 1969 World Series Champions" (https://www.mlb.com/mets/history/miracle-mets)
Note: This content was generated using artificial intelligence and may contain factual errors or inaccuracies. Please verify any important information from reliable sources.
item.itunes:summary: Mets history: Koosman's victory, Seaver's retirement, and Washington's three-homer game on June 22

item.itunes:keywords: Mets Baseball History, Tom Seaver Career, Shea Stadium, Claudell Washington, Miracle Mets

item.title: Seven Solo Shots: The Night the Mets Found Their Groove
item.itunes:title: Seven Solo Shots: The Night the Mets Found Their Groove
item.description:
A historic display of power hitting unfolded at Citizens Bank Park as the New York Mets launched seven solo home runs to snap their seven-game losing streak with an 11-4 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. Francisco Lindor, Brandon Nimmo, and Juan Soto electrified the baseball world with back-to-back-to-back home runs in a explosive third inning that set the tone for the evening. Nimmo and Soto each connected for two home runs, while Jared Young and Francisco Alvarez added their own solo shots to the historic tally. The performance tied an MLB record for solo home runs in a single game, last achieved in 2016. For Juan Soto, the night held special significance as he recorded his 27th multi-homer game before turning 27 years old, placing him among baseball's elite power hitters. The victory wasn't just about breaking records; it represented a potential turning point in the Mets' 2025 season, transforming a moment of adversity into a showcase of resilience and offensive prowess.
Learn More: • "Baseball Tonight" (https://wondery.com/shows/baseball-tonight) • "The History of the New York Mets - Book" (https://amazon.com/books/history-new-york-mets) • "MLB.TV Game Archive: June 22, 2025 - Mets vs. Phillies" (https://mlb.com/tv/g777405) • "Breaking Down the Mets' Historic Seven Homer Night" (https://www.mlb.com/news/mets-seven-homer-game-analysis)
Note: This content was generated using artificial intelligence and may contain factual errors or inaccuracies. Please verify any important information from reliable sources.
item.itunes:summary: Mets blast seven solo home runs, break losing streak with 11-4 win over Phillies, tying MLB record.

item.itunes:keywords: Baseball History, Home Run Records, Mets Victory, Juan Soto, Philadelphia Phillies

item.title: Almost Perfect: Tom Seaver's Masterpiece at Shea
item.itunes:title: Almost Perfect: Tom Seaver's Masterpiece at Shea
item.description:
Experience two of the most memorable moments in New York Mets history as Tom Seaver's masterful near-perfect game and a marathon 23-inning contest showcase the team's enduring spirit. On a sweltering 90-degree afternoon at Shea Stadium in 1969, Seaver dominated the Philadelphia Phillies, retiring the first 25 batters in order before Jimmy Qualls broke up the perfect game with a clean single to left-center with one out in the ninth. The Mets won 4-0, with Seaver striking out ten in one of Shea Stadium's greatest pitching performances. Five years earlier, on June 21, 1964, the Mets and Phillies engaged in an epic 23-inning battle that remains the longest complete game in Mets history. The marathon contest lasted seven hours and twenty-three minutes, featuring seventeen pitchers who combined to throw an astounding 658 pitches. Despite the length, only seven runs were scored, with the Phillies ultimately prevailing. These historic games exemplify the perseverance and competitive spirit that have defined the Mets franchise throughout its history.
Learn More: • "Tom Seaver's Near-Perfect Game" (https://sabr.org/gamesproj/game/july-9-1969-tom-seavers-near-perfect-game/) • "Baseball's Longest Games" (https://www.mlb.com/news/longest-games-in-baseball-history-c275773542) • "Tom Seaver: The Perfect Game That Wasn't - Documentary" (https://www.mlb.com/mets/video/seaver-s-near-perfect-game-c3531274) • "The Day the Mets Made History" (https://baseballhall.org/discover/inside-pitch/tom-seaver-nearly-perfect)
Note: This content was generated using artificial intelligence and may contain factual errors or inaccuracies. Please verify any important information from reliable sources.
